title: Joseph Interprets Dreams in Prison
summary: Genesis 40 tells how Joseph interprets the dreams of Pharaoh’s cupbearer and baker while in prison. His interpretations prove true—one is restored and the other executed. However, the cupbearer forgets Joseph.

faq.question: What were the two dreams about?
faq.answer: The cupbearer dreamed of restoring Pharaoh’s cup, and the baker dreamed of birds eating bread from a basket on his head.

faq.question: Did Joseph’s interpretations come true?
faq.answer: Yes. The cupbearer was restored, and the baker was executed, just as Joseph said.

faq.question: Are dreams only for special or holy people?
faq.answer: Nope! In the Bible, God sometimes gave dreams to all kinds of people—kings, prisoners, servants, and more. God can speak to anyone. What matters is whether the person listens and responds to what God shows them.

faq.question: What is a cupbearer?
faq.answer: A cupbearer was someone who served drinks to the king and made sure they were safe to drink. He was trusted because he protected the king from being poisoned.
